Metolius' new training and warm-up tool are a perfect blend of portability and functionality

Metolius' new training and warm-up tool are a perfect blend of portability and functionality

The post Metolius Nano Rings: A Review appeared first on Gripped Magazine.

Metolius released its iconic Metolius Simulator hangboard in 1987, an absolute game changer for athletes looking to build strength, warm up safely, and rehabilitate injuries. The Simulator took the climbing world by storm, and Metolius has been on the cutting edge of the finger training game ever since, offering several other training tools in wood and plastic, both mountable and portable. Their latest offering is their lightweight Nano Rings – portable wooden blocks you can take to the gym or crag.

The Nano Rings are sold individually or as a package of two. Each block features 10 mm, 15 mm, 20 mm and 25 mm edges, a 40 mm finger jug and a 40 mm full hand jug. You can use them for weighted lifts at the gym on any size edge you would like to train. They’re also great for some simple finger rolls and tugs as you are warming up, either for a gym session or at the crag. When using the rings as a pair, they easily do the trick for any hanging exercise you can think of.

Each block weighs 220 g (the weight of approximately three Clif Bars), making the Nano Rings a very portable companion. With dimensions of 35 mm x 80 mm x 40 mm, you don’t have to agonize over whether or not to pack it on even the most heinous slog to your climbing destination of choice.

With these weight and size specs, the Nano Rings are a little heavier and bulkier than some other wood blocks on the market, but they sturdy and designed to last. They are thick enough that you will never be afraid of the wood splintering as you train weighted lifts. And because the wood itself is robust, you would never pick them up and be concerned that they’re too flimsy to withstand your training protocol or that they might get crushed under the weight of your gear.

Personally, I think the Nano Rings are awesome. They’re a great design, balancing functionality, portability, and comfort. The wood is not too slippery, nor too rough, and the finish doesn’t immediately make your fingers sweat, as some other finishes do. I love having a large variety of edges on such a small device. The choice by Metolius to make the edges slightly positive is genius. When hung in open space, portable blocks tend to tilt under the weight of the climber. However, the slightly positive angle means that the edges will still sit horizontally, instead of slightly tipping downward and creating impossible-to-hold slimpers as you hang. I don’t notice the slightly positive angle bothering me with weighted lifts – the edges feel comfortable and safe to train on.

 

The jugs are also great for all of your needs: deadhangs, shoulder shrugs, pullups, front levers, whatever you can think of (or are capable of). Some jugs on other portable wood blocks or hangboards are uncomfortable. They can be angular, too skinny, or sometimes feature unusual notches and lines, all of which can create hot spots when you hang. It can be frustrating when you’re trying to rehabilitate an injury, but the hot spot aggravates your already irritated [insert injured body part here]. But like the edges, the jugs are pleasantly ergonomic and comfortable.

So if you’re in the market for a new portable training blocks that meets the Goldilocks standard of comfort, affordability, packability, durability, these Nano Rings are for you. Their thoughtful composition by Metolius makes them tools you will actually want to take with you to the crag and use as a part of your training routine.

title: Olympic Gold Medallist Climber Announces Retirement
content_text:
Paris 2024 speed climbing gold medallist Aleksandra Mirosław says she plans to end her career "on my own terms"

Paris 2024 speed climbing gold medallist Aleksandra Mirosław says she plans to end her career "on my own terms"

The post Olympic Gold Medallist Climber Announces Retirement appeared first on Gripped Magazine.

Paris 2024 speed climbing gold medallist and world speed climbing record holder Aleksandra Mirosław of Poland has announced she will retire from international speed climbing at the end of the 2026 World Climbing (IFSC World Cup) season.

This year, the World Climbing Series (formerly IFSC World Cup) will conclude in Kraków, Poland. Mirosław intends for this final event of the season, in her home country, to be her last. No doubt, climbers are looking forward to embracing one final season with Mirosław, who has done so much for the sport of speed climbing.

Mirosław has set multiple speed climbing world records, often breaking her own. She was the climber to establish the inaugural women’s Olympic Record in Tokyo at 6.97 seconds, and in the finals, set a new record of 6.84 seconds. In May 2022, she broke her world record and established a new one of 6.53 seconds at a qualification round at the World Cup in Salt Lake City, Utah. In April 2023, she shaved 0.28 more seconds off at the World Cup in Seoul, South Korea, resulting in a new record of 6.25 seconds. And in the European Qualifier for the Paris Olympics in September 2023, she took took her record down to 6.24 seconds.

Her latest record breaker was at the qualification heats in the 2024 Paris Olympic Games, when she climbed the speed route in only 6.06 seconds. At the games, not only did she set a new world record standard, but she also took home the Olympic Gold medal in speed climbing.

“Today is my 32nd birthday,” said Mirosław on Instagram. “For me, it’s a moment to pause for a second, a time for reflection and for looking back at the road I’ve travelled. And I think this day will stay with me forever, because today I want to share something very important with you. This idea first appeared in my heart many years ago and has been slowly growing ever since. For a long time, I knew how I wanted to say goodbye to the world of sport in this role. On top. On my own terms. My own way. And now, as I turn 32, that day has come.

“I’d like to tell you that the 2026 season will be my last competitive season in the World Cup and European Championships. Just a few final starts and then this chapter comes to a close. Sport will always remain an important part of who I am, even though my role will gradually change. There will be time to tell that story. Today’s announcement is mainly for you — for the fans who have been with me all these years. Ahead of me are the final months, competitions and training sessions, and my commitment to the work I still have to do remains unchanged. So do my goals. I’m giving this everything I have.

“Here, I’d like to invite you to join me in this final chapter and especially to Kraków, where I’ll compete in the World Cup for the last time. I don’t know how this stage will end, because in sport there are no guarantees, but I’ll do everything I can to finish it in the best way I know how.”

title: Can 3D printing preserve a potentially eroding V17 boulder? Or a stolen beloved mini-problem?
content_text:
Return of the Sleepwalker may have been climbed when it was wet. Portable went missing for months. Here’s how 3D printing could preserve classic climbs for future generations.

The post Can 3D printing preserve a potentially eroding V17 boulder? Or a stolen beloved mini-problem? appeared first on Gripped Magazine.

Return of the Sleepwalker may have been climbed when it was wet. Portable went missing for months. Here’s how 3D printing could preserve classic climbs for future generations.

The post Can 3D printing preserve a potentially eroding V17 boulder? Or a stolen beloved mini-problem? appeared first on Gripped Magazine.

In a video of a pro climber’s attempt on Return of the Sleepwalker, running water could be heard in the background. According to some, that sound is a cue precipitation recently occurred in that area.

There was also a reported send of that iconic V17 boulder on a date last year that was concerningly soon after a major rainfall event in Red Rocks.

It sparked off a conversation about the ethics of climbing after a bout of wet weather, and many raised concerns that this would increase the risk of damage to the boulder, while also setting a bad precedent.

Sandstone can become pliable in wet weather. Luckily, in the case of Return, there has been no reported damage. However, many climbers in areas like Red Rocks have an understanding that no one is to pull on holds until a sufficient amount of time has passed after rain or flood.

If this norm hasn’t already been broken, it likely will only be a matter of time. Athletes, especially those pressured by sponsors and career prospects, travel from around the world to try the problem. At some point, the gains of sending a V17 are bound to outweigh the personal cost of climbing a damp rock.

There are also a number of other contributing factors that could make Return of the Sleepwalker particularly susceptible to wear. 

Jerry Handren, the author of Red Rocks: A Climber’s Guide, said Return of the Sleepwalker is in an area that’s easy to access and sees a lot of traffic.

He didn’t have a traffic count for the iconic V17 specifically, but he told Gripped that it’s in a heavily-frequented area.

“It’s busy. Lots of people bouldering in that zone these days. Seems like there’s always someone there,” said Handren.

“[It’s] a 20-minute hike, 15-minute drive along a dirt road. Probably takes an hour to get from I-15 or the [Las Vegas] strip to the start of the dirt road most days.”

He also noted that climbing wet rock has generally been an ongoing problem in Red Rocks. 

This has led to man-made erosion on a number of climbs, changing the difficulty level both up and down. 

“Some routes get harder because chip edges lose their lips and get more rounded. This happens for cutter edges as well. Slopers often get more positive over time, a process that accelerates with brushing and accelerates even more with brushing in damp conditions.”

In some cases, he noted there might actually be an incentive to climb in wet conditions. 

“Red Rocks slopers are very condition-dependent, and, in some cases, are easier to stick after rain,” he said. “The dry, windy conditions that work for granite, for example, can make some Red Rocks slopers impossible to stick.”

Return of the Sleepwalker features an incredibly difficult sloper.

These are just some examples of how problems can change over time thanks to erosion and traffic. 

But what happens when boulders disappear altogether? 

In Squamish, Portable, a mini-boulder problem, went missing in September last year. 

The one-foot tall hunk of granite was beloved, and many were outraged at its disappearance.

Luckily, it re-emerged in Bishop in January. This extended absence raised questions about how it could or should be preserved in case of a not-so-lucky next time. 

One answer could lie with technological innovation. 3D printing has advanced to a point where professionals have been able to train on replicas of benchmark problems. 

Perhaps such replicas could also be used to preserve the original shape and form of problems for future generations.

 

Can the ‘Burden of Dreams’ approach to 3D printing preserve Return of the Sleepwalker?

When Will Bosi sent Burden of Dreams, it was a landmark in the history of the sport. 

Not only because it was a big send of a benchmark V17, but because of the method that Bosi employed. He had the ability to train on 3D printed holds that replicated the problem. 

Could a model like that apply to something like Return of the Sleepwalker?

“So I believe it’s really dependent on the style of boulder problem,” Bosi told Gripped. “Lines like Burden are far easier to replicate and preserve than lines like Return of the Sleepwalker. However, I do still believe it would be possible to replicate most boulders, but far more work would be needed, along with custom wall design.”

A problem like Burden lent itself very well to becoming a replica. It’s almost like a board climb, with a consistent angle. Making a facsimile of this climb was mainly a process of replicating individual holds. 

In the case of Burden, Bosi’s ability to train with replica holds was the result of work done by Aidan Roberts.

In 2021, Roberts scanned the holds of the problem. It was then 3D printed by someone from Germany. 

But 3D prints alone typically aren’t enough. They have a tendency to be weak and slippy, often making them unsuitable for climbing.

As a result, Core Climbing, a UK-based hold manufacturer, then got involved in the process.

In order to create holds that would be well-suited for climbing, castings had to be made. These are holds that are created by pouring material into molds.

Core Climbing took the 3D prints, gave them texture and fixation points, and created molds from them to produce finished castings that Bosi then practised on at the Lattice training centre.

Bosi has also been able to scan holds for Floatin’, an iconic V16 in Japan. Core also stepped in and manufactured holds for this famous problem, which, along with Burden’s holds, are now available to the public. 

Printing individual holds for a board-like problem is one thing, but what about a boulder like Return of the Sleepwalker, which has a much more varied surface?

Leo Moger, director at Core Climbing, said that the technology to create carbon copies of entire boulders probably exists, but cost and resources can be a limiting factor. 

First, 3D scans of the boulder have to be made. In some cases, it can be as simple as using a phone app. That’s apparently the approach that Roberts and Bosi took, he said. 

This may work if the idea is to scan small areas like individual holds. But for bigger jobs that also demand very high resolution, a phone app may not cut it. 

“You would require professional grade scanning equipment to cover a boulder face and actually achieve any sort of detail, and for the hardest lines, the fine detail matters,” Moger said.

But even sophisticated scanners aren’t a guarantee of perfect replicability.

“Even with high-end scanning, there are always tiny details that do not come through cleanly: small divots, crystals, pocket depth, and texture,” said Teresa Coimbra, a Core Climbing staffer who was present during the scanning work for Floatin’.

“Having the climber who knows the holds well is still important for checking and refining the final result.”

As with Burden and Floatin’, a 3D model would then have to be printed. The model would then be coated to form a mold, which would then allow for castings to be created.

“An entire boulder face would be quite a challenge, individual holds are of course much easier to do,” said Moger. “For Burden and Floatin’, I needed to mold and cast several times to get the details and texture correct.” 

“I think the tech is probably already there,” he said. “But the market definitely isn’t.”

Even a small project could take months to realize, he said, and they don’t recoup the outlay when compared with commercial projects.

Cost-wise, a buyer would likely have to drop something that’s easily five figures, he said.

That being said, if a project like this were to happen, here’s one way it could.

“An entire boulder could definitely be scanned to high resolution,” said Moger. “This way a library of boulders could be created on a computer, individual holds would be easy enough to pick out and 3D print, mold [and] cast.”

A full face could be printed with an enormous machine, or in multiple sections. It would then be a matter of replicating the same process used to create individual holds. The final product would need to be a glass-reinforced plastic for weight and strength, he said.

But while the shape could be replicated, there is still the question of whether plastic could ever mimic the feel of real rock.

Step into a climbing gym, and it’s very likely that many of the holds you’ll be pulling on are made from polyurethane, and, occasionally, wood.

These, however, are poor substitutes for the real thing, Moger said.

“You would want a material with high abrasion and thermal conductivity to best mimic rock,” he said. “Fortunately, polyester composites are ideal for this. They feel great, cool to touch, and have [a] long-lasting surface. You would still need to select the correct base texture prior to molding the model, but that is fairly straightforward.”

That being said, this still isn’t rock. Could something more ‘real’ be used when fashioning climbing holds?

The geologist’s approach: using minerals to 3D print sandstone

Up until now, the discussion has largely been centred around the tools and techniques used by the climbing industry. 

But geologists have been applying their own methods in using this technology to reconstruct rocks using materials rocks are literally made from. While this hasn’t been tested for climbing, it doesn’t take a big stretch of the imagination to see how it could easily apply. 

Perhaps one of the most promising of the tools Serg Ishutov has used in his career as a geologist and researcher is the sand printer.

Powder is loaded on top of the printer, which then deposits it in layers of varying thickness onto a flat platform.

Sand is unloaded, bit by bit, while a substance known as a binder is sprinkled on top of each layer. This acts as the glue for the soon-to-be rock. The process repeats with alternating layers of sand and binder until a rock emerges.

“You print a sandstone,” said Ishutov, an assistant professor at Concordia University of Edmonton. “It really looks like a piece of, you know, pebble that you can find anywhere on the beach.”

With such equipment, it may be possible to create carbon copies of boulders, he said. However, the caveat is that it depends on the material of the original rock.

Sandstone boulders would likely be feasible. But a granite problem like Portable would be a challenge, as igneous rocks are much more difficult to reproduce.

“There are powders that can replicate sand, clay, calcite, those that are coming from the sedimentary rocks,” Ishutov told Gripped. 

These types of rocks are easier to replicate, because they generally have a primary mineral, often quartz. 

Igneous rocks, he said, are more of a challenge, because they consist of a greater variety of mineral types.

The technology for replicating igneous rocks is currently in development and still needs to be streamlined, he said.

That being said, progress is being made. 

In one case, Ishutov said he paid a visit to a company in Belgium that had an instrument that showed some potential.

“It could mix different powders or different substances to produce multi-material prints,” he recalled. “So let’s say, if you want to have sandstone within limestone within granite [you could make it]…if you have the right components. So that apparatus may be able to produce it.”

While igneous rocks may still be a work in progress, making a carbon copy of a giant sandstone boulder may well be within the realm of possibility.

Generally, with the machines he’s worked with, the dimensions of a sand print are a metre by a metre, though newer technology may have increased the print size.

As a result, the process of replicating a sandstone boulder would likely involve printing individual parts of the rock and assembling them together.

Some machines also have the ability to fortify a printed rock to ensure it has the longest life possible. This would be done by introducing a reinforcing liquid or powder agent into the print.

There haven’t been any studies comparing the durability of 3D printed sandstone to its real counterpart for the use of rock climbing, but it could be a promising proposition.

“I would say that they may be comparable, because…you’re using this using similar material: [there’s] quartz in the natural sandstone and quartz in the 3D print,” said Ishutov. 

“The only difference is that natural sandstones actually can have various compositions. So in addition to quartz, they can have other minerals.”

He also noted that the composition and properties of sandstone prints could be changed to suit their purpose.

So the technology is there, and it could theoretically work. The final big question is cost. 

Ishutov estimated that assembling a 10-foot by 10-foot surface with a thickness of a couple centimetres would cost somewhere in the area of $10,000. 

This also depends on whether you own the machine or not. A print could cost anywhere from thousands of dollars if it’s ordered as a service versus hundreds of dollars if you own the equipment.

Ishutov suggests it would cost over $100,000 to buy something like the sand printer he has used: the ExOne M-Flex.

However, this model appears to have been discontinued. 

A representative from ExOne and voxeljet, which are sand printer manufacturers that are undergoing a merger, said a smaller sand printer would cost about 120,000€, or about $141,000. A larger, industrial system could cost up to $1.9 million. 

It’s a staggering cost, making it unlikely that someone would try this science experiment in the near future.

But as the sport gets more popular, there may, at some point, be a real demand for preserving its benchmark climbs just as they are now. Some deep-pocketed benefactors or sponsors may deem the cost to be worth it.

Holds can break and wear out. Access issues may bar some climbs from reach.

But a digital library of 3D scans of the sport’s most important climbs? That could live forever, waiting for the right time to be printed back into reality. Perhaps a time when technology becomes cheaper. More accessible. Or when the demand becomes most pressing.

There is some comfort in knowing that, with the right resources, gear, and know-how, someone generations from now may still be able to pull on the holds of a preserved climb, completely unchanged from how it is this moment.

title: “The most pure testpeice of all time” – Zach Galla Sends Lucid Dreaming V15
content_text:
The American boulderer recently topped one of the hardest problems graded V15 anywhere

The post “The most pure testpeice of all time” – Zach Galla Sends Lucid Dreaming V15 appeared first on Gripped Magazine.

The American boulderer recently topped one of the hardest problems graded V15 anywhere

The post “The most pure testpeice of all time” – Zach Galla Sends Lucid Dreaming V15 appeared first on Gripped Magazine.

On January 14, Zach Galla sent Lucid Dreaming V15 (8C), located on the Grandpa Peabody boulder in the Buttermilks, California. It’s the 25-year-old’s first big send since topping two V17s in a week at the beginning of December.

Lucid Dreaming is a Buttermilks classic, and a sandbag at V15, at least in the modern era of bouldering. The problem features one of hardest two-move sequences of any established line in the world. When Paul Robinson made the first ascent in 2010, he initially proposed V16. After climbing a few other problems, he made the decision to downgrade it to V15 before it received a repeat. Whatever the grade, Lucid Dreaming was a futuristic climb. It took four years for the problem to receive its second ascent, and Daniel Woods was the climber to do it.

Alex Megos was the third ascensionist, sending the problem in 2015, and he described it at the time as “the longest project I ever had.” He compared the experience of topping out as being similar to when he ascended Action Directe, the world’s first 5.14d. Since Megos’ ascent, Lucid Dreaming has be completed by several of the world’s best climbers, including Jimmy Webb, Sean Bailey, Lee Sungsu, Adam Shahar, Toru Nakajima, and David Fitzgerald, among others. Ethan Salvo recently announced his ascent of the problem, which you can learn more about here.

“Progress like this feels so good,” said Galla on Instagram after his ascent. “Whenever I’ve been in bishop, I would always have to test how I was feeling on Lucid. I sorted out the individual moves fairly quickly but the link always felt too elusive for me to even want to dedicate serious time. This go around I felt much more comfortable in the positions and with a bit of luck was able to lace it up after two short sessions, on my second proper “send try”! This has got to be the most pure testpeice of all time. Feels like a dream.”

Galla is one of the strongest boulderers in the game. On December 4, he sent his first of V17, Sean Bailey’s Shaolin in Red Rock, Nevada. Seven days later, he topped his second of the grade, Woods’ Return of the Sleepwalker, also in Red Rock. In September, he repeated America’s first V16, Woods’ Hypnotized Minds in Rocky Mountain National Park, Colorado. In addition to Hypnotized Minds, he has several absolute classic V16s to his name, including Grand Illusion, Sleepwalker, Sosa, and perhaps most impressively, the long-awaited second ascent of The Process.

title: The Climber Who Broke Both Legs and Crawled off a Himalayan Mountain
content_text:
The epic story of a first ascent and how Doug Scott survived the Ogre with two broken legs

The post The Climber Who Broke Both Legs and Crawled off a Himalayan Mountain appeared first on Gripped Magazine.

The epic story of a first ascent and how Doug Scott survived the Ogre with two broken legs

The post The Climber Who Broke Both Legs and Crawled off a Himalayan Mountain appeared first on Gripped Magazine.

The Himalayan climber, however well organized, walks a fine line between a smooth ascent and disaster. In this case, the Ogre, or Baintha Brakk, proved no exception. Chris Bonington reflected on the fragile balance, noting that on previous expeditions, “friends had lost their lives, all of them at the very end of the expedition.” This time, the team nearly followed the same pattern. It was lighthearted all the way to the top, until Doug Scott slipped. A climb that had seemed a success suddenly became a struggle for survival.

The expedition was hardly traditional. It resembled an Alpine trip with friends sharing a base and choosing routes as circumstances dictated. Doug Scott, who had initiated the trip, realized seven climbers was too many for a 24,000-foot peak. They split into two groups. Doug and Tut Braithwaite pursued a striking rock prow straight up the center of the mountain. The others, Dougal Haston, Clive Rowland, Mo Anthoine, Charlie Clarke, and Chris, took a more devious, technically easier line to the left. Tragically, Charlie Clarke, who would have served as the team doctor, had to drop out for personal reasons, and Dougal Haston died in a skiing accident in January 1977. Nick Estcourt stepped in to fill the gap.

The Ogre had already seen three failed attempts. Don Morrison led two expeditions in the 1970s but could not find a viable route up the lower slopes. In 1975, a Japanese team tried from the south, reaching around 21,000 feet but retreating due to weather and time constraints. Bonington’s team reached base camp on June 10, a triangular patch of grass squeezed between moraine and rocky slopes, just minutes from Morrison’s Latok II expedition. The camp’s atmosphere reminded Chris of Chamonix, only surrounded by unclimbed aiguilles.

Three days later, an Advanced Base was established beneath the Ogre’s southern face. Here, the routes diverged. Doug and Tut ferried gear for an alpine push to the col at the foot of their prow, while the others, jokingly called the B team, planned to fix ropes to a spur leading to a different col before continuing alpine-style. Early days saw Chris, Nick, Mo, and Clive working together on the spur. “We had all underestimated its scale,” Chris recalled. What seemed like a two-day effort ended up taking nine days to fix ropes and establish a camp at the arête’s top.

Their first setback came on June 18 when a loose rock struck Tut Braithwaite’s thigh as he and Doug carried loads. Luckily, it did not break, but it was badly bruised, forcing Doug to ferry loads alone. Meanwhile, the B team progressed steadily along their spur, negotiating short rocky steps, gullies, and snow slopes that would later turn to ice. Nick and Chris reached their ridge camp on June 20 after hauling fifty-pound loads of food meant to last ten days.

The team dynamics were different. Mo and Clive preferred a steadier pace with more rest, while Nick and Chris pushed on aggressively. The group reunited at Camp II on June 21, reinforcing the camaraderie despite differing strategies. From there, progress continued, culminating in the thrill of reaching the broad glaciated shoulder leading to the Ogre’s final mass. At 21,000 feet, level with the Baintha Aiguilles and just below Conway’s Ogre, they gazed over a panorama of unnamed, unclimbed peaks and, in the distance, the massive Nanga Parbat. Chris remembered feeling “released from all external pressures, dependent on each other alone, committed to the seemingly simple objective of the Ogre.”

On June 27, they dug a snow hole at 21,800 feet, preparing for the final push. Crossing ice-covered slabs required precarious tension traverses. Chris muttered protests while Nick urged him on, reminding him that if he backed down, Nick would have to take the lead. The bivvy was harsh. Chris remained dry under his Gortex outer, but Nick’s sleeping bag became damp from condensation. The mountain demanded every ounce of focus, endurance, and nerve.

Despite careful planning, the Ogre proved as formidable as expected. Each snow slope, rock step, and ridge demanded painstaking effort. Bonington’s account captures not just the physical struggle but the emotional tightrope that Himalayan climbers navigate, where exhilaration and peril exist side by side.

The following morning, the team began traversing toward the Ogre’s main peak. The closer they got, the more forbidding it appeared. Back at Advanced Base and on the shoulder, they had convinced themselves that the final rock tower must have lines of weakness, “perhaps around the back somewhere.” They could not believe that a 23,900-foot summit had no comparatively straightforward way to the top. In hindsight, their preparation had been minimal: only fifteen rock pegs, no étriers, and very few slings. Now, the monolithic face before them made even reaching the little col below the summit block daunting.

They were almost at the col between the west summit and the main summit. Just 300 feet below the top, yet those 300 feet consisted of steep, technically difficult rock at nearly 24,000 feet. It was past midday when the idea came to both of them simultaneously. The west summit, about 200 feet lower than the main, had an easy snow slope leading up to it. With only one cylinder of gas, a day’s worth of food, and insufficient hardware, they decided to secure a summit by taking the easier route. That afternoon, they dug a snow hole and reached the west summit the next morning, descending afterward to the shoulder. They had made the sensible choice, yet a gnawing sense of anti-climax lingered. The solid lump of the Ogre’s main summit still haunted them.

Concerns about the others weighed heavily. Why had they not come up? Reversing the traverse the following morning provided the answer. At the broad col below the end of the traverse, they found Mo, Clive, Tut, and Doug. Each party had worried about the other but had decided to pursue their own route when rescue seemed impossible. Clive had favored the steep rocks of the west ridge, arguing it was both safer and more interesting. Doug agreed, abandoning his rock prow because Tut’s leg was still problematic. Fortuitously, they found about a thousand feet of Japanese fixed rope, greatly aiding their climb.

Tragically, bad news arrived. It was not their team that had been delayed, it was a tragedy in the Latok II expedition. Don Morrison had fallen into a crevasse and died.

The discussion turned to logistics. Their pile of food mirrored what Chris and Nick had carried, barely enough for a summit push. If they could persuade the others to descend for more supplies, a renewed summit attempt could be possible. Eventually, the plan was agreed upon. The party returned to Base Camp, and two days later, Clive, Mo, and Doug began ascending again. Chris and Nick rested for two days, though both were exhausted and Nick struggled with a severely infected throat.

On July 5, the climb resumed. The day was spent at Advanced Base retrieving the gear and food Doug had left on the col. Tut and Nick soon realized they were unfit for another attempt. Chris set out alone in the early hours, undertaking a 13-hour haul to the col with a heavy sack. Meanwhile, the others had moved a tent to the shoulder below the west ridge at 22,500 feet, progressing steadily on the steep rocks. Doug led for two days, tackling VS-standard stretches, while Chris eventually joined them, finding the climbing more relaxed with the fixed ropes in place.

They faced delays from threatening weather. With one tent for the four climbers, Chris and Mo bivvied under the stars. Doug and Chris descended to the col to retrieve the spare tent. At last, on July 11, the final summit push began. Even then, they underestimated the time needed at altitude. The day’s goal was to reach the snow hole below the west summit, but the team encountered one more hard pitch. Doug led an awkward traverse on steep, precarious ground, while Chris followed, rappelling short sections and occasionally tumbling.

With fixed ropes and all four climbers together, the mood lightened, but the effort remained punishing. Progress was slow over snow traverses and rock pitches. Doug tackled the final steep wall, smooth but cleft with a thin crack. He ascended methodically, penduluming across the rock to find placements, until finally reaching the small snow shoulder. From there, Chris followed, carrying his sack and relying on Doug’s assistance.

The final couloir was snow over rock, insubstantial and strength-sapping. Doug led for nearly an hour, with Chris close behind. Then, at seven o’clock on the night of July 13, they stood on the summit of the Ogre. Exhausted and exhilarated, they had conquered one of the world’s most formidable peaks, every grueling step etched into memory.

The sun had already slipped behind Kunyan Chhish, leaving little time to savor the panorama. The Ogre dominated the Biafo region; K2 loomed as a triangular black silhouette in the far distance, merging with the blue-grey of night, while Nanga Parbat hung against the fading light to the southwest. Glaciers writhed in deep shadow in every direction. Looking down the other side, it was clear they had taken the easiest route to the summit. Yet there was no time for reflection. Chris, tired of being tail-end Charlie, offered to descend first, but Doug, having lingered on the summit for nearly an hour, was eager to move.

They fixed the rappel rope below the summit. Doug disappeared from sight, heading straight down the headwall and across the shoulder toward the peg at the top of the crack. Chris’s attention was drawn to the surrounding peaks, but a sudden, Tarzan-like yell snapped him back. Doug was nowhere in view. The rope was taut. He had slipped, swinging violently in an involuntary pendulum. Panic rose. “This might well be it,” Chris thought, assessing how to descend a rope under tension. His Jümars’ safety springs had failed, and Doug had none.

Then came a shout: “I’ve broken my legs.”

Chris asked if he could take his weight off the rope. There was no reply. After a long pause, the rope slackened. Chris carefully descended and found Doug sitting on a small ledge, secured by a couple of good nut anchors. He realized immediately the severity of the situation. Carrying an incapacitated man over the traverses or back via the west summit was impossible. He reassured Doug they would get him down, silently wondering how.

Just below them was a small snow spur. Chris rappelled, and Doug followed, sliding on his back and crawling with a rope pull to the platform Chris had dug. That night became the coldest either had endured. With neither food, stove, nor down gear, they spent hours sitting face to face, massaging each other’s toes to stave off frostbite. Doug worried particularly about his legs. Dawn brought only marginal relief, and they began the descent. Chris led, fixing rappels, with Doug following, while they debated their route. Chris favored descending directly via the path he and Nick had taken, leaving Doug at the foot to be collected by Mo and Clive. By digging large bucket steps, Doug managed to crawl to the snow cave, while the others opted to return over the west summit, following familiar terrain.

Chris spent the remainder of the day semi-comatose, his voice nearly gone. Mo took over caring for Doug’s feet, while clouds crept across the western sky, foreshadowing a storm. That night the weather broke. Spindrift infiltrated their snow hole, covering Mo’s sleeping bag and leaving the team damp and chilled.

The next morning, they brewed tea and prepared to ascend. Mo and Clive took the lead to fix a rope to the top of the west summit. Doug, on two Jümars, began his laborious ascent, kneeling in the snow and pulling himself upward by sheer strength. He could not follow the previous steps, now filled in by the storm, and relied solely on the rope and the aid of Mo and Clive for the final few feet. Chris followed behind, removing intermediate pegs. What had been a swift climb for Nick and Chris earlier now took six hours for the four men to ascend just 200 feet.

By midday, Chris reached the summit to find Doug sitting forlornly, while Mo and Clive had already begun descending. Panic flickered briefly at the sense of isolation, but Doug’s shout brought reassurance. Chris rappelled down to Clive, who waited, and Doug followed. At last, they were moving downward, but each rappel was fraught with the fear of a rope jamming. With most pegs left at the top of the rock wall or in Chris’s pack, they had only five rock pegs, a few nuts, and a single ice peg for the remainder of the descent. Every step demanded focus, courage, and a meticulous calculation of risk.

They followed Mo, searching at the end of each rope-length for the next anchor point, guided by his shouts until they reached the traverse. Mo led superbly across the snow-clad ice, and they abandoned one rope to serve as a handrail for the rest. Clive cut generous bucket steps for Doug, who crawled along with a back rope from Chris.

By dusk, they reached the site of their previous snow hole atop the rock step. Mo and Chris began enlarging it for four, a slow, exhausting process. Despite their efforts, Mo and Chris ended up exposed to spindrift, their sleeping bags soaked, and by morning Mo had no feeling in either foot.

The storm raged on. Strengthened by a weak brew of milkless, sugarless tea, they set out again. Mo pushed ahead, Doug belayed between Clive and Chris, crawling along the crest before dropping to the final steep section leading to the fixed ropes. Here, a near-disaster occurred. Mo, on the final rappel, tied off ropes to be recovered later. Doug, unaware of the dangling short end, rappelled off it, shooting down out of control, but miraculously caught the fixed rope without further injury. Chris later suffered a similar scare, plunging twenty feet before the rope stopped him, hitting a rock with a terrifying crunch. Miraculously, he was relatively uninjured, though his left wrist swelled from the impact.

Sun briefly broke through the clouds, revealing snow-plastered peaks and the bottom of the pillar where Mo had begun digging out the tents. Doug hauled himself down the final ropes, poised over the bergschrund. Suspended from a single peg, they managed to lower him safely, then followed the short stretch of steep snow to the tents. Exhausted, soaked, but alive, they collapsed, finding a small supply of milk and sugar for a brew.

The following morning, Chris felt the effects of his fall. Previously energetic, he now felt drained, suspecting pulmonary edema. Despite his concern, the storm raged, delaying their descent across the plateau. On July 19, the weather finally eased. Mo led the descent, followed by Doug, with Clive and Chris bringing up the rear. Chris, weak and light-headed, cleared ropes and carried his heavy sack and 300 feet of rope in slow, painstaking steps. They reached the head of the fixed ropes above the arête, and Mo hauled Chris down the slope while roped together. Once on the dry glacier, they unroped and Mo surged ahead, while Chris staggered behind, resting every fifty paces. By three o’clock, he saw Base Camp, but it was deserted. A note and cache of food revealed that Nick and Tut had been forced to descend due to limited supplies, leaving Mo to race down for help.

Clive and Doug had arrived at Base the previous night, exhausted and battered. They spent three days waiting, until Nick, with twelve porters, arrived to rescue the party. Doug endured two more cold, uncomfortable days on a makeshift stretcher, while Chris hiked in a daze down the Biafo Glacier. A helicopter evacuation was delayed due to a crash at Skardu, leaving Chris weak and coughing frothy fluid, a sign of pulmonary trouble, but finally, six days later, he was flown to Islamabad, a bearded, filthy skeleton in red silk underpants and a blue sweater, clutching an ice axe and down gear.

Looking back, the descent overshadowed the climb. It was an epic journey, full of danger, perseverance, and narrow escapes. There was never true despair, though there were moments of terrifying loss of control. Chris admitted worry only after his own fall, but the team had to keep moving. Doug’s own stamina and self-reliance had been crucial; the party’s limited assistance, careful rope management, and ample snow-melting fuel made survival possible. Without liquids, they could have been in serious trouble within five days.

Upon returning to Britain, Chris felt irritation at the media portraying them as “conquerors of the Ogre.” He preferred to think of the mountain as a great, cunning cat: allowing them to climb, playing with them on the descent, and finally letting them escape, mauled but intact, to face other mountains in the future.

Doug Scott on Surviving the Himalaya

Sources: American Alpine Journal, Alpinist, The Ogre Biography of a mountain and the dramatic story of the first ascent by Doug Scott.

They hope to climb the South African Route in under 24 hours

They hope to climb the South African Route in under 24 hours

The post Tommy Caldwell and Siebe Vanhee Take on a Patagonia Big Wall Challenge appeared first on Gripped Magazine.

Two of the world’s best big-wall free climbers are in Patagonia, hoping to accomplish a mighty goal: climbing the South African Route on the Central Tower of Paine in under 24 hours. They have already climbed it twice, each time gaining valuable insights that will help them with their single-day push.

“The first time it took us 19 days, the second time it took us 18 days,” said Vanhee on social media. “Now we are trying to get it done in a 24 hour push… Difficult route finding, questionable rock quality and some wet slabs…. Welcome to Patagonia! 10 hours of climbing with a 1 hour, 30 minute rest on a ledge, we made it to the waterfalls at pitch 14. What an experience climbing through the night in such a wild place. The send wasn’t for that day but it sure was a great recon mission.”

The 30-pitch South African Route on the east face of the Central Tower of Paine in Chile was first climbed in 1973/74 by South Africans Michael Scott and Richard Smithers at A4/5. Arthur McGarr or the Mountain Club of South Africa, wrote this about the ascent in the American Alpine Journal, “The east face of the Central Tower must be one of the finest, and most sustained rock routes in the world. The exposure never lets up as it is possible to see the glacier between one’s feet for the entire way up to the summit cone.”

The first free ascent came in February 2009 by Nico Favresse, Sean Villanueva O’Driscoll, and Ben Ditto after 13 days. “We encountered some amazing free climbing pitches with very sustained climbing mostly in the 5.11 range, almost never below 5.10+,” said Favresse here after their climb. “We estimate the 2 hardest pitches around 7b+/5-12c. One of them is a very pumpy fingertip enduro corner, while the other is a face climbing boulder problem with a spectacular sequence using a crystalline pocket. We added one bolt to protect this free variation (away from the aid line). Another main free crux of the route is a mega sustained steep 5.11+ offwidth, which was very run out with the only number 6# Camelot we had. Three of the pitches were redpointed after the summit due to icy conditions.”

In 2023, Tyler Karow, Cedar Christensen, and Imanol Amundarian repeated the South African Route. “We managed to summit on day eight in perfect weather and sent the final crux on day nine in the rain,” said Karow (story here).

Both Caldwell and Vahnee have made history in Patagonia before. In 2024, Vanhee made the first free ascent of Riders on the Storm with Villanueva O’Driscoll and Favresse (story here). And in 2014, Caldwell and Alex Honnold completed the first ascent of the Fitz Traverse (VI 5.11d C1), which they received a Piolet d’Or for (story here).

title: Switzerland Has a New V16 with Nicolai Užnik’s Full Gem

The line is a sit-start to the future-classic Forgotten Gem V15

The post Switzerland Has a New V16 with Nicolai Užnik’s Full Gem appeared first on Gripped Magazine.

Nicolai Užnik recently made the first ascent of a new problem in Ticino, Switzerland. His line is called Full Gem, and it goes at V16 (8C+). Full Gem is a sit-start version of Forgotten Gem V15, a climb Užnik almost flashed last  January, but ultimately got on his second go. The send of Full Gem comes just barely one year after the V17 climber first tried it, as he explains below, and marks his third V16.

“What a day out in Chironico, finally wrapping up this project,” said Užnik on Instagram. “I did Forgotten Gem almost exactly a year ago, and in the same session started working on the sit start. It adds a couple of quite basic but hard moves that make the whole line significantly harder. Such a special moment when everything clicked!”

Forgotten Gem was established in February 2022 by Kim Marschner. The following month, Aidan Roberts and Yannick Flohé made the second and third ascent, respectively, on the same day. Will Bosi, Nico Perlorson, and Zach Galla are among the other top climbers to tick the line. The problem ascends a stunning, sheer face etched with little edges, which make for heinous crimps.

Užnik has been taking down V15 with progressive ease over the last couple of years. His built a solid climbing pyramid, with a robust foundation of V14s and V15s. He now has three V16s under his belt, including his FA of Full Gem. In March 2023, he made the first post-break ascent of Emotional Landscapes V16 in Maltatal, which was V15 before the breakage. He also climbed Bosi’s Brain Rot V16 in November 2025, and while he said it was likely V15, he still took the grade, but dubbed it soft.

In October last year, he climbed his first V17 when he made the first ascent of Mount Doom V17 in Maltatal, Austria. A low start to the popular Hide and Sick V14, his ascent of Mount Doom made Užnik one of eight climbers to join the V17 club in 2025. Jakob Schubert made the second ascent of Mount Doom in November 2025, confirming the grade. This month, Užnik tested his strength on a Burden of Dreams V17 replica in preparation for an upcoming trip to Finland to session the real thing.

title: The Rescue of a Climber Left for Death on Mount Everest 20 Years Ago
content_text:
Lincoln Hall narrowly survived a 2006 ascent of Mount Everest thanks to four climbers who abandoned their summit bid to save him

The post The Rescue of a Climber Left for Death on Mount Everest 20 Years Ago appeared first on Gripped Magazine.

Lincoln Hall narrowly survived a 2006 ascent of Mount Everest thanks to four climbers who abandoned their summit bid to save him

The post The Rescue of a Climber Left for Death on Mount Everest 20 Years Ago appeared first on Gripped Magazine.

On May 25, while descending from the summit, Lincoln Hall was left for dead at an altitude of 8,700 metres. Hall had fallen ill with a form of altitude sickness, likely cerebral edema, which caused hallucinations and severe confusion.

Reports indicate that his Sherpa guides attempted to rescue him for hours, but as night fell, their oxygen supplies ran low and snow blindness set in. Ultimately the team left Hall, who appeared to be dead, and returned to camp. A statement was later issued to inform his friends and family that he had died.

Twelve hours later, Hall was found alive by a team of climbers, Daniel Mazur, Andrew Brash, Myles Osborne, and Jangbu Sherpa, just below the Second Step. He was partially clothed, without oxygen, food, or water, sitting near a 10,000-foot drop. Despite frostbite and confusion, he was alive and coherent enough to respond to them.

Osborne described the scene just below the Second Step to Everest News in the story “Update: Myles Osborne for SummitClimb Everest Tibet, Dispatch 28th May 2006”: “Sitting to our left, about two feet from a 10,000 foot drop, was a man. Not dead, not sleeping, but sitting cross legged, in the process of changing his shirt. He had his down suit unzipped to the waist, his arms out of the sleeves, was wearing no hat, no gloves, no sunglasses, had no oxygen mask, regulator, ice axe, oxygen, no sleeping bag, no mattress, no food nor water bottle. ‘I imagine you’re surprised to see me here’, he said. Now, this was a moment of total disbelief to us all. Here was a gentleman, apparently lucid, who had spent the night without oxygen at 8600m, without proper equipment and barely clothed. And ALIVE???”

A rescue effort later described as “unprecedented in scale” quickly swung into action. Mazur and the others bailed on their summit attempt to stay with Hall. At the same time, expedition leader Alexander Abramov sent a team of 12 Sherpa guides from base camp.

Hall was carefully brought down, walking the final stretch to Everest’s North Col, where he was treated by Russian doctor Andrey Selivanov. He reached Advanced Base Camp the following day, still suffering from frostbite and the effects of cerebral edema. Hall ultimately lost the tips of several fingers and a toe to frostbite.

His survival and rescue occurred shortly after the death of British climber David Sharp on Everest. Sharp had been left unattended while unconscious but alive, as others continued their ascents. The incidents sparked international concern, including from Sir Edmund Hillary, and a mention in the book High Crimes: The Fate of Everest in an Age of Greed.

Mazur said after the rescue, “The summit is still there and we can go back. Lincoln only has one life.”

In 2006, the documentary Left for Dead on Mount Everest aired on Dateline NBC and was nominated for an Emmy Award. Hall also authored two books about his ordeal: Dead Lucky: Life after Death on Mount Everest (2007) and Alive in the Death Zone: Mount Everest Survival (2008). Another documentary, Miracle on Everest, based on Dead Lucky, premiered in 2008 on the National Geographic Channel. Hall died in 2012 at the Royal Prince Alfred Hospital in Sydney, Australia, after battling mesothelioma.

Williams is the latest to repeat Daniel Woods' Return of the Sleepwalker V17

Williams is the latest to repeat Daniel Woods' Return of the Sleepwalker V17

The post Over 100 Sessions Later, Nathan Williams Tops His First V17 appeared first on Gripped Magazine.

Nathan Williams has just announced his send of Return of the Sleepwalker V17 (9A) in Red Rock, Nevada. In his own words, it was a battle, spending over 100 sessions to unlock the problem. He sent Sleepwalker V15/16 back in December 2020, but didn’t try ROTSW, the sit-start version of Sleepwalker, until 2022.

Sleepwalker was put up by Jimmy Webb in 2018. A few years later, Daniel Woods established ROTSW in March 2021. Woods’ first ascent was historic, as ROTSW became the first V17 in the United States. Will Bosi made the second ascent in February of 2024. Noah Wheeler then made the third ascent in December that year.

“The epic battle is over, I just didn’t want the boulder to win,” said Williams on Instagram. “When I first tried this boulder in 2022 the shoulder method for the bottom was the only beta that had been done. In later seasons, easier beta was found for the bottom, and while it made climbing through the bottom consistent and faster, it felt wrong—it was tweaky on my wrist and not the original challenge I sought out to complete. Last season, I barely had any desire to try it because I hated the new beta for the bottom. This year, I chose to switch back to the shoulder beta. While more physically difficult, the original beta was a more enjoyable experience for me and was exactly the challenge I had dedicated myself to throughout the previous years.”

ROTSW saw a lot of action in 2025. Simon Lorenzi, Ryuichi Murai, Zach Galla, and Adam Shahar made the fourth, fifth, sixth, and seventh ascents, respectively. With Williams’ send, ROTSW has now seen a total of eight ascents, making it the most repeated V17 in the world. Alphane has six ascents, Burden of Dreams and Soudain Seul have five, and Shaolin has four. All other V17s either remain unrepeated or have only seen one repeat.

Before ROTSW, Williams’ hardest send was Daniel Woods’ Creature from the Black Lagoon V16 in Rocky Mountain National Park, Colorado, which he topped in September 2024. He sent Sleepwalker V15/16 at the end of 2020. He has lots of other hard boulders to his name, including The Wheel of Wolvo V14 at Lincoln Lake, Colorado, Brass Knuckles V14 in Dayton Pocket, Tennessee, and Esperanza V14 in Hueco Tanks, among others.

title: Climbing in Paradise: San Vito Lo Capo
content_text:
The re-birth of the Sicilian sport climbing destination

The post Climbing in Paradise: San Vito Lo Capo appeared first on Gripped Magazine.

The re-birth of the Sicilian sport climbing destination

The post Climbing in Paradise: San Vito Lo Capo appeared first on Gripped Magazine.

This article was originally published in the August/September 2025 print issue of Gripped Magazine under the authorship Jessica Kuepfer and Aaron Pardy.

San Vito Lo Capo is a town located on the northwestern tip of Sicily. Known internationally by sun seekers for its white sand beach under the dramatic Monte Monaco, rock climbers have been flocking to the area for decades for the gorgeous seaside limestone. Although the area is informally referred to as San Vito, the climbing is found across a few locations, including San Vito Lo Capo, Macari, Castelluzzo, and Custonaci —all within a short drive from each other.

Development of the area really started to pick up in the mid-2000s, with bolters Daniele Arena, Josef Gstöttenmayr, and Jim and Scott Titt leading the way. There are now around 1,300 sport routes in San Vito, ranging from 5.4 to 5.14d. Over 40% of these climbs are rated 5.10b and under, perfect for those climbing in the lower grades. San Vito also houses nearly two dozen multi-pitch climbs up the mighty Monte Monaco, most fully bolted, with a few trad adventures here and there.

At first glance, San Vito Lo Capo is a climbing paradise, but its breathtaking Mediterranean views have come at a cost. The area has suffered from bolt corrosion due to its marine environment, a problem that has plagued many climbing areas around the world, most notably Railay/Tonsai in Thailand. Reports of bad bolts and anchors began to surface about San Vito in the 2010s, and the area went from being a sport climbing hotspot with huge potential to relative obscurity, at least outside of Europe.

Although there are still plenty of climbers visiting during climbing season, San Vito has undoubtedly suffered from its ‘bad bolts’ reputation. The popularity of climbing has grown rapidly over the past ten years, and we can’t help but wonder how prominent of a climbing area San Vito would currently be if it didn’t suffer hardware issues.

Recognizing the corrosion problem, a slow but steady re-bolting effort began in the late 2010s. Anchors were updated, bolts chopped and replaced, and entire crags were equipped with new gear—some with titanium, the best possible material to use close to the sea. Arena led much of this re-bolting effort, while other developers instead chose to bolt entire new crags with higher quality materials than in the past.

Covid slowed these re-bolting efforts and hardware continued to corrode in the elements. In 2025, a new titanium re-bolting fundraising initiative was launched by local climber and hostel owner, Marco Peralta, along with Arena. Already very successful, the grassroots campaign has raised more than $20,000 CAD from hundreds of individual donations. You can donate to the bolt fund here.

This money has already gone towards re-bolting some of San Vito’s most iconic sectors, but there is a ton of more work to be done. In our opinion, hundreds of routes in the area are due for a re-bolt, a task that will take tens of thousands of dollars (or Euros) to complete.

While bolt corrosion happened at a rapid pace in San Vito, every sport climbing area on the planet will eventually face what San Vito is trying to overcome. Bolts, regardless of material and location, do not last forever and will eventually need replacement. Sport climbing routes are a precious resource, and they need to be managed as such, requiring monitoring and funding to ensure they continue to exist in a safe state into the future. Without passionate individuals like Peralta and Arena, and continued donations to the re-bolting effort, San Vito climbing would surely rust away into oblivion, which would be a real shame for our sport.

Now is a great time to visit San Vito. With more and more state-of-the-art hardware being installed, San Vito is getting a second life. The rock is incredible, the setting is stunning, the approaches are easy, the locals are friendly, the food is amazing, and the climbing crowds are minimal compared to other high-profile sport climbing destinations. If you operate at 5.10 and under, it’s hard to think of a better place for a climbing getaway.

About the climbing

The rock in San Vito is unique and diverse. Some crags were sculpted by the sea long ago, leaving eye-catching rounded features and a texture more similar to sandstone. Other crags involve steep cave climbing on bullet-hard tufas, stalactites, and wild tufa-blob concretions. The limestone ranges in colour from bright white to fiery red, with stripes of brown, grey, and black.

No matter the grade, you can find awesome limestone features and interesting five-star lines. In San Vito, the “easy” climbing is as enjoyable as the “hard” climbing, with cool holds, funky features, and thoughtful moves. Bolt counts are generally friendly, and a large spread of grades at most crags means that partners and groups of mixed abilities can all find something to climb.

The majority of climbing is found along the Scogliera di Salinella, a seaside cliff band over four kilometes in length. At the north end of this wall of rock, you’ll find Cala Mancina is one of the most scenic group of crags, with nearly all grades and styles being covered in a relatively short section of stone. The nearby Zoo crag might appear to be a humble wall. But the well-bolted easy climbs are incredibly fun, offering climbers in the 5.10-and-under range a chance to pull on neat features usually only found on harder routes.

The middle section of the Scogliera di Salinella is dominated by Bunker, a huge white wall with an old World War II bunker sitting on top. The crag features a totally different experience on its unique white rock—undulating and technical, with the odd jam or two to leave you grinning ear to ear. Around the corner you’ll find Canalino, with some spectacular rock that you’d swear is sandstone, and Grotta della Palma, a cool cave and headwall with some incredibly good 5.12 climbs.

At the southern end of the wall, you’ll find many crags, some easy, some hard. The popular Pipeline area offers a super short approach and a stunning, colourful wall of pockets, huecos, crimps, and slippery slopers.

Other crags are dotted throughout the region. Crown of Aragon, our favourite crag in the area, offers seriously fun climbing on overhanging, bomber orange rock plastered with stalactite features. While the intimidating Never Sleeping Wall in Custonaci is home to jaw-dropping lines, the stone is often seeping, and many routes could use a re-bolt (more on bolts and conditions below). Nuova Ossessione offers similarly epic climbing, with huge 40-metre lines on slightly overhanging or vert terrain filled with tufas, stalactites, and pockets—but a significantly longer approach.

When to visit

The best time to climb in San Vito is from October to April, with ideal conditions in November. It’s a great winter destination, with most crags getting all-day or afternoon sun. Climbing is possible—even pleasant—through December, January, and February, although this time of year can be a little rainy. In the summer, San Vito Lo Capo becomes very busy with beach goers. While climbing is still possible for determined, early risers, it is tourist season and the hottest time of year.

How to get there

San Vito Lo Capo is located about 1 hour and 15 minutes from Palermo by car. You can find transfers from the airport to San Vito Lo Capo and back. Car rentals are affordable and conveniently located at or near the airport (usually with free shuttles). Having a car makes places like Crown of Aragon, Never Sleeping Wall, Nuova Ossessione, and others much more accessible. It should be noted, however, that a car is not absolutely necessary as there are plenty of walkable crags along the Scogliera di Salinella (depending on where you stay).

Accommodation 

There are endless options for accommodations in San Vito Lo Capo. There are many B&B’s and hotels, often fitted with kitchens or kitchenettes. There are also a few campgrounds. The El Bahira Camping Village is a popular spot for climbers at the southern end of the Scogliera di Salinella, offering tents, mobile homes, and villas right in front of hundreds of climbs, including the popular Pipeline sector. The Climbing House, run by Arena, is another great option just a few minutes’ walk from the Cala Mancina crags.

The Timbuktu Hostel is wonderful place to stay in the heart of San Vito Lo Capo. Owned and operated by Peralta, it’s by far the coolest hostel we’ve visited. He also runs a small but well-stocked gear shop at the hostel called SV Climbing.

About the bolting

Hundreds of routes in San Vito have bolts that are made of A2 (304) stainless steel, drilled into the rock in the period between the mid-2000s and mid-2010s. A2 bolts have a long history of failure in seaside settings, in San Vito and elsewhere. Although extreme corrosion and bolt failures have primarily occurred in steep cave formations in San Vito, on paper, there are an awful lot of bolts with the potential to fail.

When we were climbing and scoping out the bolts in San Vito, we noticed that many A2 bolts appeared to be in excellent condition to the naked eye. But you never know what lies under the surface. We also saw many older A4 (316 and 316L) and even duplex bolts that were highly corroded, screaming for a titanium re-bolt.

We personally chose not to climb on any routes equipped with A2 bolts while on our trip, and we still had more than enough routes to choose from, climbing on A4, duplex, and titanium. As part of the recent re-bolting campaign, Peralta and Arena are sharing awareness about the hardware issues through social media and signs at the crags. They are also closing routes with particularly sketchy bolts, flagging them with red ribbons.

Climbers are strongly encouraged to report any problems they see and to donate to the bolt fund. Peralta and Arena have set a goal of reaching €50,000 (~$80,000 CAD), targeting the most potentially dangerous areas with old A2 hardware.

Conditions

Other than hardware corrosion, the only other negative about San Vito is the conditions. They can be downright tricky to understand and manage, particularly for hard climbing where wind, humidity, sun, and shade can make or break a send.

San Vito is windy, and when the winds are dry, the conditions are amazing. Unfortunately for climbers, these winds can often be humid, leaving the rock feeling soapy and slippery. Condensation is a significant problem in the area. Some crags are condensed for weeks at a time. When it gets really bad, you can even observe little salt crystals that have deposited on the rock from the humid breezes.

Other walls seem mostly immune to the issue. Most cliffs are somewhere in between. Often a climb will feel great until you reach a humid pocket, crack, or flake. If you make it past the gooey hold, your hands will feel slimy for the next set of moves. Brushing is very helpful for improving friction.

The sun is another thing to manage. If you don’t mind climbing in the sun, you have plenty of options as most crags face south, west, or southwest. Otherwise, early starts are the name of the game, so you can complete your climbing day before the sun hits the wall midday. While there are a few north-facing crags, they are a rarity, and it is not uncommon for the approach to be a spiky, bush-whacking adventure depending on the time of year.

After heavy rainfall, many crags seep, as is typical of tufa- and stalactite-featured limestone. There is sometimes a delay in the seepage, meaning that a wall might be dry after a day of heavy rain, but damp a couple of days later. Vert and slab walls tend to dry quickly, but any wall with caves and tufa features are prone to seepage after heavy, prolonged rainfall.

Guidebook

There are a few different guidebooks for the area, and each comes with its own pros and cons. The most recent is Sicily Rock by Ulrich and Harald Röker. It’s a great guide with easy-to-use picture topos and approach instructions. In the latest 2024 edition, they included bolt type information for most climbs, helping you pick areas and routes with good gear. The book doesn’t include the 2025 titanium re-bolt information for Cala Mancina, Cala Mancina Grotta, and Grotta dei Santi.

Published in 2021 by Rockfax, Sicily by Daimon Beail is another great book. Like Sicily Rock, it has great picture topos and approach instructions. Unlike Sicily Rock, it doesn’t include bolt quality information, but it does include route descriptions and climbing areas in Palermo.

If you’re looking to climb all around the island of Sicily, Versante Sud’s Di Roccia di Sole by Massimo Cappuccio and Giuseppe Gallo is the book to get. Published in 2022, it includes San Vito, Palermo, and many other climbing areas throughout the island. You can buy the guidebooks online or at SV Climbing in San Vito Lo Capo.

Food

Sicily has a reputation as a gastronomic capital. There are many restaurants in San Vito Lo Capo, but if you visit during the winter, all but a few will be closed for the season. Bakeries are abundant and offer restaurant-quality food on a budget. There are several grocery stores, greengrocers, and supermarket chains like Conad and Supermercati Deco in town. The cheese and meat counters are a vision for anyone who loves a good charcuterie board, and the fresh pasta offerings are fun to explore if you enjoy cooking.

Some local delights you shouldn’t miss include arancine (deep fried rice balls stuffed with bolognese, cheese and spinach, or cheese and prosciutto), sfincione (a pizza-like offering with a spongy dough topped with tomatoes, onions, cheese, anchovies, bread crumbs and/or olive oil), pane e panelle (a sandwich filled with chickpea fritter), couscous (there is even an annual couscous Festival in San Vito Lo Capo) and Caldo Freddo (sponge cake soaked in rum, topped with hot chocolate, ice cream, and whipped cream).

Rest days

It takes roughly four hours to drive the island from east to west. And while it isn’t a massive distance to cover, you could spend a lifetime exploring all that Sicily has to offer. There is something for everyone: archaeological sites, cathedrals, palaces, beaches, scenic hikes, and concerts for lovers of every musical genre.

If you want to combine your history fix with a day at the spa, the ancient Greek temple and theatre of Segesta and the Segesta Hot Springs are only a one hour’s drive away. If you would like a change of scenery, the charming medieval town of Erice is less than an hour away, perched atop a mountain with breathtaking views.

The capital of the province, Trapani, is a 50-minute drive from town. Here you can go shopping, stroll along the harbour front, visit the salt flats, and stay for dinner and a show at one of its many theatres, or find live music at a bar.

Next to San Vito Lo Capo, you’ll find the Riserva Della Zingaro, offering endless scenic trails overlooking the sea. You also can’t miss the beautiful beaches in San Vito Lo Capo and Macari, as well as the gorgeous swimming area near the Cala Mancina crags. If you’re a mountain biker, you can rent bikes through Arena at The Climbing House.

You will most likely fly into Palermo, and should plan to spend at least a day or two in the city, rich in history, culture, art, music, and food.

Other climbing in the region

Bosco Scorace is less than an hour away features some fantastic bouldering, with over 400 lines on primo sandstone. If you didn’t bring your pads, you can rent them from the nearby B&B Polvere di Stelle. The bouldering gym Dolmen Climb is one hour away in Trapani, and is well worth the visit for some training or climbing on a rainy day. Palermo also has a lifetime of sport climbing in and around the Mondello neighborhood.

title: Can Lindsey Vonn Race the Olympics with a Torn ACL? An Expert Weighs In.
content_text:
Vonn tore her ACL in a crash just days ahead of the Milan-Cortina Olympics. An orthopedic surgeon for skiers says her comeback will hinge on one specific moment.

The post Can Lindsey Vonn Race the Olympics with a Torn ACL? An Expert Weighs In. appeared first on Outside Online.

Vonn tore her ACL in a crash just days ahead of the Milan-Cortina Olympics. An orthopedic surgeon for skiers says her comeback will hinge on one specific moment.

The post Can Lindsey Vonn Race the Olympics with a Torn ACL? An Expert Weighs In. appeared first on Outside Online.

As if the Lindsey Vonn comeback couldn’t get any more dramatic.

Unless you’ve been hibernating in a cave, you may have read that Vonn, the comeback queen of American ski racing, is enduring a rollercoaster ride in the final days before the Milan-Cortina Winter Olympics.

After dominating the Downhill World Cup in November and December, Vonn, 41, crashed hard on January 30 during a warmup run ahead of the Crans-Montana World Cup. As far as ski racing crashes look, this one appeared bad—Vonn had to be airlifted from the slope.

A few days later, she announced the extent of the damage: a ruptured anterior cruciate ligament (ACL), bone bruising, and damage to her meniscus. Despite these wounds, Vonn told reporters that she is powering ahead toward the women’s Olympic Downhill, which will be held on Sunday, February 8.

“Every day my knee’s gotten better,” Vonn told The Associated Press on February 3. “And every day we’re discussing with a full medical team, doctors, physios, everyone, to make sure we’re doing everything to make sure I am making smart and safe decisions.”

What a Doctor Says About Lindsey Vonn’s Torn ACL

Since then, the Internet has been abuzz with experts weighing in on Vonn’s decision to race, despite her injured knee. The ACL connects your thigh bone (femur) to your shin bone (tibia), and provides stability to your leg when your knee is bent. Sounds pretty important, right?

Well, it turns out that other elite skiers have competed despite having torn the tendon. Three weeks after tearing her ACL, Italian downhiller Sofia Goggia won a World Cup race in 2022. Vonn even raced in the 2014 Olympics in Sochi with an ACL tear.

I recently spoke to Dr. Kevin Stone, an orthopedic surgeon in California and ACL expert, who was also the U.S. Ski Team’s doctor from 1988 until 2002. Dr. Stone told me an ACL tear during skiing is usually traumatic and leaves an athlete hobbled and with agonizing pain.

“What typically happens when you rupture the ACL skiing is you jam the tibia forward into the femur, the tibia bruises the bone and tears the stabilizing meniscus cartilage,” he said. “That combo leads to swelling and pain and instability right away.”

Yeah—not exactly the condition you’d want to be in when hurdling down an icy ski slope at 70 miles per hour.

When I brought up the fact that other ski racers have competed with a torn ACL, Dr. Stone laughed and reminded me that “not every ACL tear is the same.”

“When you hear about athletes who skied well on their ACL, it’s often because they tore it a while ago and then learned to accommodate skiing without it,” he said. “But yes, there are pro athletes who are able to accommodate a somewhat unstable knee and still perform.”

Dr. Stone characterized these patients as having a “chronic” ACL tear—it’s a long-lasting injury that is sometimes not fixed. Vonn’s tear is acute—she is only a few days removed from the crash.

I’m simplifying Dr. Stone’s analysis of Vonn’s injury here: the timing of it totally sucks. Had she ruptured the ACL several weeks ago, her body and brain would have time to heal and adjust to the injury. But Vonn only has a few days until go-time.

Still, Vonn has sounded confident in her decision to go forward. So has her coach, Chris Knight.

“I’m pretty confident that she can still pull off this dream,” Knight told The Associated Press on February 4. “I’ve got no doubts in my mind that this is going to be OK.”

Dr. Stone told me that Vonn, Knight, and the rest of the world will find out whether or not she can compete in Cortina at the exact same time. Her first training descent on the Cortina Downhill course will be the make-or-break point, Dr. Stone said.

“If she can do a training run, then the likelihood that her injuries are too severe to compete is low,” he said.

Vonn was slated to complete a practice run on the Cortina course on Thursday, February 5. But bad weather and heavy snow have now pushed the practice run back to Friday, February 6.

Thus, American ski racing fans—and more than a few orthopedic surgeons—will be watching Vonn’s run while crossing their fingers, knocking on wood, and rubbing lucky rabbits’ feet during the descent. Dr. Stone told me he will be one of them.

“We may get our answer the first time she tries to arc a turn, and definitely the first time she goes off a jump,” Dr. Stone said. “We’re all going to be holding our breath.”

I know I will be.

title: Want to Live in a National Park Rent-Free? Here’s How.
content_text:
Do you dream of living in the heart of a national park rent-free? From Yosemite to the Grand Canyon, here’s how people are doing it.

The post Want to Live in a National Park Rent-Free? Here’s How. appeared first on Outside Online.

Do you dream of living in the heart of a national park rent-free? From Yosemite to the Grand Canyon, here’s how people are doing it.

The post Want to Live in a National Park Rent-Free? Here’s How. appeared first on Outside Online.

Imagine living in the heart of Yosemite Valley or on the rim of the Grand Canyon without paying a dime for rent. If that sounds like a dream come true—well, it can be a reality. The National Park Service (NPS) is now hiring summer campground hosts for national park sites across the United States.

A recent roundup by National Parks Traveler highlighted campground host positions open for the summer of 2026 at a number of popular national parks. But there are far more positions than that available. Outside’s recent search of available NPS camp host jobs revealed nearly 60 different roles at locations ranging from Yosemite to Devil’s Tower, Bryce Canyon, North Cascades, and Lake Mead.

How Do I Apply?

For starters, you need to create a profile on Volunteer.gov, the federal government’s portal for recruiting and managing volunteers. Unlike some federal jobs, if you want to be a camp host, you don’t apply to a general pool. Instead, you apply to specific listings at individual parks.

You can use the filters on the left side of the search tool to search for positions by agency. The filter tool also allows you to search by city or state, and eliminate jobs that don’t offer lodging space.

Prior camp hosting, customer service, or maintenance experience is a plus. Participants will also usually need a valid U.S. driver’s license and their own RV or trailer to live in. The listing typically specifies the max size and hookup situation. For example, some sites offer water and sewage, but no electricity.

Some hosting jobs allow for tent camping; others offer furnished cabins. One role at Dinosaur National Monument in Colorado, for example, comes with an electric golf cart and a furnished one-bedroom apartment.

Competition is fierce for campground hosting jobs at ultra-popular parks like Yosemite. If you don’t have much prior experience, it’s smart to apply at a location that’s lesser-known, like this summer hosting job at Buffalo National River in Arkansas.

What Does Being a Campground Host Entail?

The vast majority of campground host jobs are unpaid. Compensation is a free campsite or RV hookup. In exchange, every host job has different requirements depending on its location.

Most camp host jobs involve working outside for most of the day. Hosts are responsible for keeping the campground and fire pits clean, performing basic maintenance, restocking the toilets, and assisting visiting campers with check-in. Hosts also serve as the eyes and ears of park rangers, patrolling the grounds and ensuring campers follow the rules. You aren’t expected to enforce these rules, but you are expected to report to the park’s law enforcement.

Some camp host jobs also have very specific (but usually mellow) requirements. This camp host position at Mammoth Cave requires the ability to lift at least 25 pounds. The role at Arizona’s Chiricahua National Monument states that hosts must be able to walk at least one mile per day.

Many national parks have dedicated pages on their websites that explain the role, such as this page for Great Basin National Park in Nevada. You can also find all available camp host jobs and detailed information on Volunteer.gov.

When Should I Submit My Application?

The NPS processes applications on a rolling basis, and the most sought-after destinations, like Yosemite, fill up quickly. So if you want to trade your office chair for a campfire this summer, dust off your resume and hit submit sooner rather than later.
